questions.text: Identify the Mallampati class of this patient?
Under NVBDCP, the drug combination shown below can be given under which dose combination?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 80 mg, 480 mg

 

According to National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) guidelines, the combination of Artemether and Lumefantrine (as shown in the image) is given in the dose of 80 mg Artemether and 480 mg Lumefantrine for adults (body weight >34 kg), administered as 4 tablets (each 20 mg/120 mg) twice daily for 3 days. Hence, Option A (80mg, 480mg) is correct, used for treatment of Uncomplicated Malaria by Plasmodium falciparum in NORTH EASTERN STATES of INDIA.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Artemether: A fast-acting artemisinin derivative → rapidly kills malaria parasites (including gametocytes).
  • Lumefantrine: A longer-acting antimalarial → prevents recrudescence by killing remaining parasites.

 

Note: First-Line Treatment of Uncomplicated P. falciparum Malaria (India, NVBDCP):

 

 

Additional Points:

 

  • Primaquine (single dose) is added in all regions to clear gametocytes and prevent transmission.
  • Severe malaria (all over India): IV Artesunate is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents for an elective hernia repair. The patient has a forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) of 60% predicted and requires supplemental oxygen on activity. Under what ASA-PS classification would you place him?

Ans. C) ASA 3

 

This patient has severe COPD with functional limitation, so ASA 3 is appropriate. Because, ASA 3: Severe systemic disease, with functional limitation (e.g., FEV1 60%, needs O₂ on activity).

A 56-year-old man presents with a facial lesion as shown in the image below. On examination, the lesions are painful & the edges are well demarcated & raised. Ear is also showing similar erythematous lesions. This infection is most likely to be caused by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Group A streptococcus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Group B streptococcus: Group B streptococcus (GBS) primarily causes infections in newborns and pregnant women but is an uncommon cause of skin infections in healthy adults. When it does cause skin and soft tissue infections, it is usually in immunocompromised patients or those with diabetes., although it rarely might present with classical erysipelas-like lesions.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus commonly causes skin infections such as boils, abscesses, and cellulitis but usually has indistinct borders and may produce pus. It is generally responsible for cellulitis.

 

Option D. Hemophilus influenzae type b: Hemophilus influenzae type b commonly causes respiratory tract infections, meningitis, and epiglottitis, especially in children.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is endogenously transmitted disease in India?

choices.text: Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and aerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and night time
Aerobic during day time and night time

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Oxidation Pond?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time

 

Oxidation ponds are shallow sewage treatment ponds where natural processes involving sunlight, algae, and bacteria treat wastewater. During the daytime, oxygen is produced by algal photosynthesis, making the pond aerobic. At night, photosynthesis ceases and oxygen is consumed by microorganisms, leading to anaerobic conditions. This cyclic variation is a hallmark of oxidation ponds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anaerobic during day time and aerobic during night time: This is incorrect because sunlight is essential for algae to produce oxygen; hence, aerobic conditions are always linked to daytime, not nighttime.

 

Option C. Anaerobic during day time and night time: If this were true, the pond would resemble a septic tank, not an oxidation pond. It would fail to utilize algae-mediated oxygenation.

 

Option D. Aerobic during day time and night time: Continuous aerobic conditions are not possible since oxygen is not produced at night, making this option incorrect

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the OPD due to a skin condition. For the last 3 years, he has had small "pimples" on the posterior surface of her upper arms. The lesions are associated with mild pruritus during the winter months but are otherwise asymptomatic, and the patient is primarily concerned due to their appearance when he wears short-sleeved tops. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient's skin condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratosis pilaris

 

The most likely diagnosis is keratosis pilaris. Keratosis pilaris is characterized by multiple small, rough, follicular papules, commonly on the extensor surfaces of the upper arms, thighs, cheeks, or buttocks. The condition manifests as "chicken skin" with asymptomatic or mildly itchy lesions, which worsen in dry weather (especially winter). It is a benign, inherited disorder of keratinization, causing keratin plugs in hair follicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folliculitis: Typically presents with inflamed, erythematous, sometimes pustular lesions due to infection of hair follicles, often accompanied by pain or tenderness.

 

Option C. Miliaria: This is heat rash, showing tiny, clear vesicles or papules from sweat duct blockade, occurring in hot, humid conditions rather than the chronic follicular pattern here.

 

Option D. Pseudofolliculitis: Causes papules and pustules from ingrown hairs, often in shaving areas (beard, groin).

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 2 years old child was playing with marbles and suddenly went limp and became unresponsive. Mother of the child was beside and saw him collapse. What is the first step to be done my mother in the situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Call emergency medical services

 

  • In a sudden unresponsive child, the first priority is to activate the emergency response system. Immediate EMS call ensures:
  • Rapid arrival of trained personnel
  • Access to advanced airway and resuscitation equipment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Feel for pulse and assess the breathing: While pulse and breathing check is important, calling EMS first (or simultaneously if another adult is present) is recommended by Pediatric Basic Life Support (BLS) guidelines for witnessed collapse.

 

Options C and D Back thrusts and Heimlich maneuver: Back thrusts or Heimlich maneuver are used for choking when the child is conscious and actively choking, not for sudden unresponsiveness.

questions.solution: Ans. A) Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles

questions.text: A farmer presented to the outpatient department with a non-tender, non-mobile, non-compressible firm swelling over his palm as shown in the image. A few months back he got injured with a thorn. What is the presentation given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Implantation dermoid

 

The most likely diagnosis for this painless, firm, non-mobile swelling in the palm after a thorn injury is implantation dermoid. An implantation dermoid develops when epidermal or dermal cells are implanted into the subcutaneous tissues following trauma—such as a thorn prick—leading to a slowly growing cystic lesion. These cysts are most commonly seen in the hands, especially in people with a history of prior penetrating injury. The cyst is typically non-tender, firm, non-compressible, and not fixed to overlying skin or deeper tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ameloblastoma: Is a rare, typically benign tumor arising from odontogenic epithelium, primarily affecting the jawbone, especially the mandible near molars. It causes painless swelling and slow expansion of the jaw, sometimes leading to facial deformity, malocclusion, or tooth displacement.

 

Option B. Embryogenic dermoids: Are congenital cystic lesions arising from entrapment of ectodermal tissue during embryologic fusion. They are most commonly located along the midline structures of the head, face, or neck and appear shortly after birth or in early childhood

 

Option C. Sequestration dermoids: Develop congenitally from isolated islands of ectoderm during embryogenesis, often located on the scalp or in periorbital regions. These cysts contain skin adnexal structures and keratin debris.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to hair loss. Two weeks ago, she suddenly developed loss of large numbers of hair fibers when washing or brushing her hair. The patient has had 2 pregnancies; the first led to a spontaneous abortion at 13 weeks, and the second led to a normal term vaginal delivery 4 months ago. She subsequently experienced severe postpartum unipolar major depression requiring psychiatric hospitalization. Current medications include fluoxetine and olanzapine. Arrange following parts of Anesthesia machine according to increasing pressure (from low to high):

 

1. Vaporizer mounting devices

2. Hanger yoke assembly

3. Flow meter assembly

4. Pipelines
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-3-4-2

 

  • Anesthesia machine pressure zones:
  1. Low-pressure system: Includes vaporizer mounting devices and flowmeters; pressures typically < 15 psi.
  2. Intermediate-pressure system: Includes pipelines from central supply: ~50 psi.
  3. High-pressure system: Includes hanger yoke assembly and cylinders: 45–2200 psi depending on cylinder size.
  • Arranging the given parts from lowest to highest pressure:
  1. Vaporizer mounting devices (low)
  2. Flow meter assembly (low)
  3. Pipelines (intermediate)
  4. Hanger yoke assembly (high)

The skin shows scattered, large erosions and a few flaccid bulla. Light rubbing of uninvolved skin causes easy separation of the epidermis. Punch biopsy of the skin is performed. Which of the following would be the expected findings?

questions.text: A 28-year-old male admitted with the history of road traffic accident and sustained injury to the right upper limb. This patient was planned for open reduction and internal fixation with plating for both bone-fracture right forearm under brachial plexus block. Inj. Lignocaine with adrenaline was used to decrease the bleeding and systemic toxicity. The maximum dose of lignocaine with adrenaline could be used for this patient to obtain adequate blockade is:
A 30-year-old female came with chief complaints of vaginal discharge with lower abdominal pain and cervical motion tenderness. which color kit will you prescribe her?

A 24-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to skin lesions on her trunk and proximal upper limbs. The patient noticed the lesions after returning from a summer vacation at a Goa beach a week ago. During the vacation, she had sun exposure on several occasions without prior application of sunscreen. The lesions are mildly itchy but not painful. Medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malassezia globosa infection

 

  • The image shows hypopigmented, scaly macules and patches on the trunk, commonly seen after sun exposure.
  • This is classic for Tinea versicolor (Pityriasis versicolor), caused by the lipophilic yeast Malassezia globosa (previously M. furfur).
  • Lesions are hypopigmented or hyperpigmented due to fungal interference with melanin production.
  • Mild itching may be present, especially after sweating or heat exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune melanocyte injury:

 

  • Refers to vitiligo.
  • Produces depigmented (chalk-white), well-demarcated macules, not scaly patches.
  • Vitiligo is non-pruritic and progressive, not linked to sun/heat exposure.

 

 

Option B. Dermatophyte skin infection:

 

  • Dermatophytes (Trichophyton, Microsporum, Epidermophyton) cause ringworm (tinea corporis).
  • Lesions are annular, erythematous, scaly patches with central clearing, not hypopigmented diffuse patches like in this case.

 

 

Option D. Ultraviolet skin damage:

 

  • Sunburn causes erythema, pain, blistering.
  • Chronic UV exposure causes photoaging and actinic keratoses, not multiple hypopigmented macules.

All of the following are contraindications of neuraxial blockade except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spinal deformity

 

Spinal deformity (e.g., scoliosis, mild kyphosis) is not an absolute contraindication, though it may make technical placement difficult. Experienced anaesthesiologists can often perform the block safely using landmarks or ultrasound guidance. Thus its an example of Relative Contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Absolute contraindications of neuraxial blockade include:

 

Option B. Patient refusal: Patient autonomy is paramount.

 

Option C. Local infection at puncture site: risk of introducing infection into CNS.

 

Option D. Papilledema: Increased intracranial pressure / Papilledema – risk of brain herniation.

 

List of Contra-indications for Neuraxial Blockade:-

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Factories Act?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories

questions.text: A child learning the steps of handwashing. This is known as what kind of learning:

A 19-year-old woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of chronic acne. Over the last 6 months, the patient has tried several over-the-counter acne treatments without improvement. She has a history of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder and mild intellectual disability. Her mother has a seizure disorder, and her maternal grandmother died of kidney failure. Vital signs are within normal limits. Facial examination findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberous sclerosis

 

The most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition is tuberous sclerosis.

 

The image shows numerous red papules clustered on the nose and cheeks, consistent with facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum). In the clinical scenario, the patient has chronic treatment-resistant facial "acne," a history of mild intellectual disability, and a family history of seizures and renal disease—all classic for tuberous sclerosis complex. Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in TSC1 or TSC2, leading to hamartomas in multiple organs, including the skin (angiofibromas), brain (seizures, intellectual disability), and kidneys (angiomyolipomas, cysts, renal failure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fabry disease: Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by alpha-galactosidase A deficiency leading to globo-triaosyl-ceramide accumulation. It presents with angiokeratomas—small, dark red to black papules—typically involving the lower trunk, groin, and upper thighs. Systemic involvement includes neuropathic pain, kidney failure, and cardiac abnormalities.

 

Option B. Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1): NF1 is a genetic disorder characterized by café-au-lait macules, cutaneous and plexiform neurofibromas, axillary/inguinal freckling, and Lisch nodules of the iris. It does not cause acneiform or angiofibroma-like facial lesions. Learning disabilities and skeletal abnormalities can be associated.

 

Option D. Von Hippel-Lindau Disease: Von Hippel-Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant cancer syndrome with hemangioblastomas of the retina and central nervous system, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. It primarily presents with tumor-related symptoms.

A researcher is interested in studying whether there is an association between neural tube defects and use of acetaminophen during the first 3 months of pregnancy. He randomly chooses a group of women who have just delivered babies with neural tube defects, and a second group of women who delivered apparently healthy babies. These 2 groups were then asked about their use of acetaminophen during the first 3 months of pregnancy. Which of the following measures of association are the investigators most likely to report?
Which of the following is the most peripheral centre under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Designated Microscopy Centre

 

The Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC) is the most peripheral unit under RNTCP. It is located at the sub-district level and provides sputum smear microscopy services for diagnosis and follow-up of TB patients. It serves as the first point of diagnostic contact in the hierarchy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. District TB Centre: Functions at the district level and supervises TB control activities, but it is not peripheral—it is administrative.

 

Option B. Intermediate Reference Laboratory: Located at the state/regional level, mainly involved in culture, drug sensitivity testing, and quality control, far from the peripheral structure.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis Unit: Supervises several DMCs (covering about 5 lakh population) but still above them in the hierarchy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the OPD due to upper and lower limb skin lesions that have been present for the past week. The lesions started as small, red papules that gradually enlarged but are not painful or pruritic. The patient had similar lesions several months ago and was told that the antibiotic prescribed for a dental infection could be the cause. The lesions spontaneously resolved in about 2 weeks. There is no mucous membrane involvement. Which of the following is most likely related to this patient's skin condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Recurrent episodes of painful genital ulcers

The marker has very high sensitivity and specificity for myocardial tissue. The clinical cardiology team would like to use a 99.7% reference range to assess patients who come to the emergency department with chest pain and have a high pretest probability of cardiac ischemia. Assuming a normal distribution with a mean of 0.06 U/mL, which of the following most closely approximates the corresponding reference range?

Mr. Ramesh, who is 35-year-old, works in a factory and lives with his pregnant wife and a child in an apartment. His younger brother and his wife come to visit him for one month. You are conducting a family survey in the area and will classify this family as:
Which of the following is not weaning mode of ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CMV

 

  • CMV (Continuous Mandatory Ventilation):
    • CMV delivers fully controlled breaths at a set tidal volume and rate, regardless of whether the patient initiates spontaneous breaths.
    • Because the ventilator completely takes over breathing, the patient’s respiratory muscles do not get used, which can lead to muscle atrophy and delayed weaning.
    • Primary use: CMV is typically used for patients who are apneic, heavily sedated, or during anesthesia, where spontaneous breathing is either absent or undesirable
    • Not suitable for weaning: Since the patient is not required to breathe spontaneously, CMV cannot gradually transition a patient to independent breathing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SIMV (Synchronized Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation): Used for weaning; allows patient-initiated breaths between mandatory ventilator breaths.

 

Option C. PSV (Pressure Support Ventilation): Weaning mode; patient controls breathing while the ventilator provides pressure support.

 

Option D. CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure): Weaning mode; spontaneous breathing with positive pressure to maintain alveolar recruitment.
